SENT.plain: Computed tomography (CT) and ultrasound were used to evaluate two patients with Klippel-Trenaunay (K-T) syndrome
Bowel and bladder hemangiomas were demonstrated in these cases
Computed tomography demonstrated multiple low attenuation areas in the liver and spleen in one case
Computed tomography is capable of noninvasively demonstrating bowel and bladder wall hemangiomas in K-T syndrome
Both CT and ultrasound may reveal silent lesions in the upper abdominal viscera, such as liver and spleen
